34EC9857A88B468B9374201B0E857291.description: Recognize angle measure as additive. When an angle is decomposed into non-overlapping parts, the angle measure of the whole is the sum of the angle measures of the parts. Solve addition and subtraction problems to find unknown angles on a diagram in real world and mathematical problems, e.g., by using an equation with a symbol for the unknown angle measure.

670FCE4AE7624C088DAEC0AB2E623EB6.description: Measure angles in whole-number degrees using a protractor. Sketch angles of specified measure.

12B1A7A0B7554A56A81FBF82A5D5FABD.description: Recognize angles as geometric shapes that are formed wherever two rays share a common endpoint, and understand concepts of angle measurement.            Clarification 1: e-degree angle,‚Äù and can be used to measure angles.        Clarification 2: An angle that turns through n one-degree angles is said to have an angle measure of n degrees.

4724B2025E264270912B1F5C1892C31A.description: Make a line plot to display a data set of measurements in fractions of a unit (1/2, 1/4, 1/8). Solve problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions by using information presented in line plots. For example, from a line plot find and interpret the difference in length between the longest and shortest specimens in an insect collection.

5D6BB3E360074AC1B2BBAD4D255809F9.description: Standard 3:   Geometric measurement: understand concepts of angle and measure angles.

3AFEB15AB012427FB6C52605DE30B5E7.description: Apply the area and perimeter formulas for rectangles in real world and mathematical problems. For example, find the width of a rectangular room given the area of the flooring and the length, by viewing the area formula as a multiplication equation with an unknown factor.

1A35FF41F4C04260ACA342CCF6A63292.description: Use the four operations to solve word problems involving distances, intervals of time, and money, including problems involving simple fractions or decimals. Represent fractional quantities of distance and intervals of time using linear models.                                                                                                                       (Computational fluency with fractions and decimals is not the goal for students at this grade level.)

DDD87E99F1BD405A9C0D40D914A2C7AC.description: Know relative sizes of measurement units within one system of units including km, m, cm; kg, g; lb, oz.; l, ml; hr, min, sec. Within a single system of measurement, express measurements in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit. Record measurement equivalents in a two-column table. For example, know that 1 ft is 12 times as long as 1 in. Express the length of a 4 ft snake as 48 in. Generate a conversion table for feet and inches listing the number pairs (1, 12), (2, 24), (3, 36), ...

33B17761419E461CAE1F6629CFF4A9DE.description: Standard 1:   Solve problems involving measurement and conversion of measurements from a larger unit to a smaller unit.

1A8B8C18552E49009A3ADCFF35848C14.description: Recognize a line of symmetry for a two-dimensional figure as a line across the figure such that the figure can be folded along the line into matching parts. Identify line-symmetric figures and draw lines of symmetry.

76335F7812CD494CB155F0D884C8D624.description: Classify two-dimensional figures based on the presence or absence of parallel or perpendicular lines, or the presence or absence of angles of a specified size. Recognize right triangles as a category, and identify right triangles.

3BD2E8A2D493474B9B1315C6CAE5265D.description: Draw points, lines, line segments, rays, angles (right, acute, obtuse), and perpendicular and parallel lines. Identify these in two-dimensional figures.

0AED6C8096134591BDAF73B31307D765.description: Standard 1:   Draw and identify lines and angles, and classify shapes by properties of their lines and angles.

BE1FB5A6683D4DB089FE8FB50208D661.description: Generate a number or shape pattern that follows a given rule. Identify apparent features of the pattern that were not explicit in the rule itself. For example, given the rule ‚ÄúAdd 3‚Äù and the starting number 1, generate terms in the resulting sequence and observe that the terms appear to alternate between odd and even numbers. Explain informally why the numbers will continue to alternate in this way.

46843F9FDA6A469C924EA8A4663615EA.description: Investigate factors and multiples. Clarification 1:  Find all factor pairs for a whole number in the range 1‚Äì100. Clarification 2: Recognize that a whole number is a multiple of each of its factors. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1‚Äì100 is a multiple of a given one-digit number. Clarification 3: Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1‚Äì100 is prime or composite.

E89516F1BFA24FA8A175415146ED8A2F.description: Determine the unknown whole number in an equation relating four whole numbers using comparative relational thinking. For example, solve 76 + 9 = n + 5 for n by arguing that nine is four more than five, so the unknown number must be four greater than 76.

7E7B6FC78FA54EF8B50831530E19DF4E.description: Determine whether an equation is true or false by using comparative relational thinking. For example, without adding 60 and 24, determine whether the equation 60 + 24 = 57 + 27 is true or false.

3D8D8AB3B4EF4F8AA6129F3181DBC569.description: Solve multistep word problems posed with whole numbers and having whole-number answers using the four operations, including problems in which remainders must be interpreted. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding.

248F2E26C11B49149039A7D3822894EA.description: Multiply or divide to solve word problems involving multiplicative comparison, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem, distinguishing multiplicative comparison from additive comparison.

292F583A414C45F88A7C81FF8C4F7C5F.description: Interpret a multiplication equation as a comparison, e.g., interpret 35 = 5 √ó 7 as a statement that 35 is 5 times as many as 7 and 7 times as many as 5. Represent verbal statements of multiplicative comparisons as multiplication equations.

2A72316948C1409CB74DDF50D5FA627E.description: Standard 2:   Gain familiarity with factors and multiples.

7EFF3A2E0FC04EA0942B4D4D70F9E141.description: Standard 1:   Use the four operations with whole numbers to solve problems.

7C06814845DB4D3B9185A99119B1E464.description: Compare two decimals to hundredths by reasoning about their size. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two decimals refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by using a visual model.

4FA221FE11EE461E83C5EA656A3F1E0F.description: Use decimal notation for fractions with denominators 10 or 100. For example, rewrite 0.62 as 62/100; describe a length as 0.62 meters; locate 0.62 on a number line diagram.

AE5BA437E00845DE98507897E1839307.description: Express a fraction with denominator 10 as an equivalent fraction with denominator 100, and use this technique to add two fractions with respective denominators 10 and 100. For example, express 3/10 as 30/100, and add 3/10 + 4/100 = 34/100.

EC9C47CA876547959A0BDD24ABDD2163.description: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication to multiply a fraction by a whole number.                                                                                          Clarification 1: Understand a fraction a/b as a multiple of 1/b. For example, use a visual fraction model to represent 5/4 as the product 5 √ó (1/4), recording the conclusion by the equation 5/4 = 5 √ó (1/4).                                                     Clarification 2: Understand a multiple of a/b as a multiple of 1/b, and use this understanding to multiply a fraction by a whole number. For example, use a visual fraction model to express 3 √ó (2/5) as 6 √ó (1/5), recognizing this product as 6/5. (In general, n √ó (a/b) = (n √ó a)/b.)                                                                       Clarification 3: Solve word problems involving multiplication of a fraction by a whole number, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem. For example, if each person at a party will eat 3/8 of a pound of roast beef, and there will be 5 people at the party, how many pounds of roast beef will be needed? Between what two whole numbers does your answer lie?

F8061E57AD9447AF8FD8A8CAF5EF7EFD.description: Understand a fraction a/b with a > 1 as a sum of fractions 1/b.                  Clarification 1: Understand addition and subtraction of fractions as joining and separating parts referring to the same whole.                                             Clarification 2: Decompose a fraction into a sum of fractions with the same denominator in more than one way, recording each decomposition by an equation. Justify decompositions, e.g., by using a visual fraction model. Examples: 3/8 = 1/8 + 1/8 + 1/8 ; 3/8 = 1/8 + 2/8 ; 2 1/8 = 1 + 1 + 1/8 = 8/8 + 8/8 + 1/8.             Clarification 3: Add and subtract mixed numbers with like denominators, e.g., by replacing each mixed number with an equivalent fraction, and/or by using properties of operations and the relationship between addition and subtraction. Clarification 4: Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions referring to the same whole and having like denominators, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.

52C9716F27914274B141D62A66EA5321.description: Standard 3:   Understand decimal notation for fractions, and compare decimal fractions. (Major Cluster)

3733FFE76D1B4D83A511C0B648D1810E.description: By the end of the 4th grade students should be fluent in all computational operations -  addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. Addition and subtraction fluency is determined using fact-families up to 12.  Multiplication and division fluency is determined by factors up to 12, and related division facts.

980D214C5D2A463F90C4A7D652EE4DD4.description: Find whole-number quotients and remainders with up to four-digit dividends and one-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

C05FDCC28D054D728576C89A15941106.description: Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-digit numbers, using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

E1F11C9880A04273A7CCABF32BEC9864.description: Add and subtract multi-digit whole numbers with accuracy.

DB2CBA9895A848C7B82F3BC89CB99C0B.description: Standard 2:   Build fractions from unit fractions by applying and extending previous understandings of operations on whole numbers.

2BBD90ED067846DDA071148AFBA05D02.description: Compare two fractions with different numerators and different denominators, e.g., by creating common denominators or numerators, or by comparing to a benchmark fraction such as 1/2. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.

9755F3BC0B46466488610E30BACBB537.description: Explain why a fraction a/b is equivalent to a fraction (n √ó a)/(n √ó b) by using visual fraction models, with attention to how the number and size of the parts differ even though the two fractions themselves are the same size. Use this principle to recognize and generate equivalent fractions.

D95720F26D0D4068ABF8D422497F1AAA.description: Standard 1:   Extend understanding of fraction equivalence and ordering.

B0A6008B7E1D460A9F26522CEE67B265.description: Strand:  Numbers and Operations in Base Ten - Fractions

A907175789064E9AA5DDD493F43A565C.description: Use place value understanding to round multi-digit whole numbers to any place.

1511150803DB4432AB32638C20765DC5.description: Read and write multi-digit whole numbers using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form. Compare two multi-digit numbers based on meanings of the digits in each place, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.

BCC3B8EA35884B538D84B1D1237C3A46.description: Recognize that in a multi-digit whole number, a digit in one place represents ten times what it represents in the place to its right. For example, recognize that 700 √∑ 70 = 10 by applying concepts of place value and division.

1026B82AA42C4BD099E23DD8DB7ADA5E.description: Standard: 2   Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.

89FB40E38833443E93CE536520D60B8F.description: Standard 1:   Generalize place value understanding for multi-digit whole numbers.

BBA94A100EF2466DB662964DF5C91B6C.description: Strand:  Numbers and Operations in Base Ten
